and I will throw it off. What slave
will not, if he may, escape from his chains?
Look, I weep: for more than two years
I have never enjoyed one moment
free from anguish. I have often
desired to die; but, Herbert, I am a
very coward. It is hard for one so young
who was once so happy as I was;
voluntarily to divest themselves of all
sensation and to go alone to the dreary
grave; I dare not. I must die, yet
my fear chills me; I pause and
shudder and then for months I shall
endure my excess of wretchedness. But
now the time is come when I may
quit life, I have a friend who will not
not to accompany me in this dark
journey; such is my request: earnestly
